meta.title: Number Systems - Exercise 1.2 (Short Answer Questions with Reasoning)

questions.question: Let $x$ and $y$ be rational and irrational numbers, respectively. Is $x + y$ necessarily an irrational number? Give an example in support of your answer.
questions.solution:
Answer: Yes

Justification: The sum of a rational number and an irrational number is always irrational.

Example: Let $x = 2$ (Rational) and $y = \sqrt{3}$ (Irrational).
Then $x + y = 2 + \sqrt{3}$, which is an irrational number.

questions.question: Let $x$ be rational and $y$ be irrational. Is $xy$ necessarily irrational? Justify your answer by an example.
questions.solution:
Answer: No

Justification: The product of a rational number and an irrational number is irrational only if the rational number is non-zero. If $x=0$, the product is rational.

Example: Let $x = 0$ (Rational) and $y = \sqrt{2}$ (Irrational).
Then $xy = 0 \times \sqrt{2} = 0$, which is a rational number.

questions.question: State whether the following statements are true or false? Justify your answer.
parts: (ii) There are infinitely many integers between any two integers.
(iii) Number of rational numbers between 15 and 18 is finite.
(iv) There are numbers which cannot be written in the form $\frac{p}{q}$, $q \neq 0$, $p, q$ are integers.
(v) The square of an irrational number is always rational.
(vi) $\frac{\sqrt{12}}{\sqrt{3}}$ is not a rational number as $\sqrt{12}$ and $\sqrt{3}$ are not integers.
(vii) $\frac{\sqrt{15}}{\sqrt{3}}$ is written in the form $p/q$, $q \neq 0$ and so it is a rational number.
questions.solution:
(i) False. $\sqrt{2}$ is irrational. Quotient of irrational by non-zero rational is irrational.

(ii) False. There are finite integers between two integers (e.g., between 1 and 3 is just 2).

(iii) False. There are infinitely many rational numbers between any two distinct rational numbers.

(iv) True. These are called irrational numbers (e.g., $\sqrt{2}, \pi$).

(v) False. Example: $(\sqrt[4]{2})^2 = \sqrt{2}$, which is irrational.

(vi) False. $\frac{\sqrt{12}}{\sqrt{3}} = \sqrt{\frac{12}{3}} = \sqrt{4} = 2$, which is a rational number.

(vii) False. $\frac{\sqrt{15}}{\sqrt{3}} = \sqrt{5}$, which is irrational. For a number to be rational, $p, q$ must be integers.

questions.question: Classify the following numbers as rational or irrational with justification:
questions.solution:
(i) $\sqrt{196} = 14$ (Rational)

(ii) $3\sqrt{18} = 3(3\sqrt{2}) = 9\sqrt{2}$ (Irrational)

(iii) $\sqrt{\frac{9}{27}} = \frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}$ (Irrational)

(iv) $\frac{\sqrt{28}}{\sqrt{343}} = \sqrt{\frac{4}{49}} = \frac{2}{7}$ (Rational)

(v) $-\sqrt{0.4} = -\sqrt{\frac{4}{10}} = -\frac{2}{\sqrt{10}}$ (Irrational)

(vi) $\frac{\sqrt{12}}{\sqrt{75}} = \sqrt{\frac{4}{25}} = \frac{2}{5}$ (Rational)

(vii) $0.5918$ is a terminating decimal (Rational)

(viii) $1+\sqrt{5}-4-\sqrt{5} = -3$ (Rational)

(ix) $10.124124... = 10.\overline{124}$ (Rational, repeating)

(x) $1.010010001...$ (Irrational, non-terminating non-repeating)
